properties.description: With water guarding the tee shot, players will want to drive to the right side of the fairway. Long hitters can fly the water. A long green with narrow opening is guarded by a large trap on the right. The approach must be played well in any hopes of getting a birdie.

This hole is a long par 5. Long hitters will get tempted to “give it a rip” and look to get on the green in two. Green should be approached by left side to avoid short bunkers. This hole should give up some birdies.

This one is a short par 3 made dif cult by swirling winds. Players hope to stick the wide, narrow green. The waste bunker may catch errant shots to the left. Far right pin location brings Little Eagle Creek into play. The heavily contoured green makes putting a challenge.

This short par 4 requires players to have an accurate tee shot. Pin placements on the left side of the green force players to land their tee shots to the right of the unique fairway bunker. Severely sloped green leads to dif cult putting positions.

This hole requires a challenging tee shot with OB left and bunkers right. Most players will have to layup over the creek on the landing to the right of the green. A severely undulating green demands accuracy with approach shot.
The ladies will face a short but intimidating tee shot, a shot that must hug Little Eagle Creek to have a chance for a clear approach to the green. Long, rolling green will make putting a challenge.

This long par 3 stresses an accurate tee shot. Little Eagle Creek stands between the tee box and the green. A large green allows for many dif cult pin locations. The spectator mount on the left affords great views.
The historic barn gives players a target. Pot bunkers guard the front left edges of the green. The green slopes toward the creek; players would be smart to leave approach shots below the hole.

On this short par 4, the ladies will aim for the right side of the fairway, leaving an easy approach to the green. Missed tee shots to the left will result in a blind approach. Gently sloping greens should yield some birdies.
On this long snaking par 5, golfers will need to approach the green from the left. If the green is missed right it will end up in a deep swale. Sloping, elevated greens create dif cult putts.

On this short par 4, drives need to be aimed to the right of the fairway for players to have an open shot at the green. Ladies who end up on the left side of the fairway will be blocked from the green. This severely sloped green must be approached at the right tier of the pin position for any shot at birdie.
This is a short but difficult par 3. Little Eagle Creek and a long trap guard the left, leaving a safe landing area to the right. Birdie is a great score on this hole.
Players will aim for the right side of the fairway, but avoid the long deep bunker. Drives to the left will leave a blind shot to the green. Large undulating green makes for severely breaking putts.

As the longest par 5 on the course, an errant tee shot will make for a dif cult second shot. Deep bunkers guard the left side of the green. This is a good scoring hole and has potential for many birdies.

Players will enter inside the track and approach this dif cult par 3. Tee shots that miss the green will roll to the bottom of the valley, leaving a tough pitch back to the green. Huge sloping green allows for interesting pin positions.

On this scenic par 4, golfers tee off over a lake bordered by sections of retaining wall from the racetrack. The lake guards the entire left side of the hole, coming into play on drives and approach shots. Large green allows for dangerous pin placements near the water’s edge.

This hole is a short par 4. It is important for players to hit the narrow fairway. Trouble will ensue if missed as the hole is surrounded by 26 bunkers. With the right pin location birdies should be achievable.

This  nishing hole is expected to see many birdies which should lead to lots of drama heading into Saturday’s  nal round. With a bunker running the length of the fairway players will want to stay right. Further right is a mound perfect for spectators. A short second shot should set up a lot of birdie tries.
